newsitem.title: EGYPT: Sudan says its human rights record is improving.
newsitem.headline: Sudan says its human rights record is improving.

text.p: Sudan reacted calmly on Tuesday to recent criticisms of its human rights record.
Foreign Minister Ali Osman Mohammad Taha told a news conference in Cairo that the country's record was improving and was better than those of many countries in the region.
He did not challenge the substance of the reports, which alleged that torture is widespread and that the Sudanese authorities have used violence against trade unionists.

The minister, referring to a recent critical report by the U.N. Human Rights Commission, said: "The report in its general contents represents a step that is relatively better than the reports which came out in previous years.

"If we look at the accusations against Sudan, compared with those against many other states in the region, we will find that Sudan, given the wars it is living through,...is in a much better position than many of the countries."
"Those who try to exploit the principles of human rights to put political pressure did not find anything to reinforce what they have said about Sudan on previous occasions," he added.
The minister attributed the relative improvement to what he said was Sudan's policy of allowing human rights organisations to visit the country and see the facts on the ground.

In one report issued last week, a committee of the International Labour Organisation denounced violence against trade unionists -- including murder, disappearances, and intimidation -- in Colombia, Nigeria and Sudan.
A separate report by the U.N. special rapporteur on torture, listed Sudan among 29 countries where he said torture was a fairly extensive problem.
